Identifying Characteristics: Adults are usually green or greenish-brown with an off-white underside blotched with yellow or gray
Adults have teeth in the roof of their mouth and a muscular tongue that can flip prey into their mouth
Limbs are typically blotched or banded with gray
Size: Males are smaller than females and be anywhere inbetween 3” and 6” in length
Biology: Mating occurs roughly from late May to July and males call out unique songs to draw females to ponds
Females lay eggs in shallow water among vegetation and can lay up to tens of thousands of eggs and fertilization occurs in water
Eggs hatch within a week after fertilized and tadpoles emerge
As the tadpoles continue to grow they move into deeper waters
Metamorphosis from a tadpole to an adult can take any amount of time between a few months to a few years depending on temperatures (colder temperatures mean longer development time)
Lifespan is generally eight to ten years
Habitat: Vegetation along the edge of large, slow-moving bodies of water, or the body of water itself
Diet: Tadpoles feed on single-celled algae, protozoans, pollen grains, and other small particles trapped in the filtration organs in their pharanges
Adults will eat anything that it can swallow—including invertebrates and small vertebrates such as mammals, birds, reptiles, fish, even turtles and other frogs
Range: Eastern United States—ranging from as far north as Nova Scotia, all the way down to central Florida
Also native as far west as Wisconsin and the Rockies and were introduced widely throughout Colorado, British Columbia, California, and other western states
